{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3419580,"name":"Kanaan Kratzer","username":"Kanaan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/2bfe46/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T22:27:56.192Z","cooked":"

Just out of curiosity, (and since SPARK MAXs are considerably more expensive than a Neo/neo550) if you have two motors that you want to always spin at the same speed and direction, could you, FRC legally, hook them both up to the same SPARK MAX and would they still work properly?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T22:27:56.192Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":47.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470519,"topic_slug":"motor-controlling","display_username":"Kanaan Kratzer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57510,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/motor-controlling/470519/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3419584,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T22:34:31.785Z","cooked":"

For the Neo/Neo550, not legally, no. See R505.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-08-30T22:58:41.801Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470519,"topic_slug":"motor-controlling","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2024/rule/R505","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"R505","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/motor-controlling/470519/2","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3419587,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-30T22:39:23.026Z","cooked":"

This does not work for brushless motors. Brushless motors work by the controller successful changing which electromagnets in the motor are turned on or off based on the position of the motor. That’s why you have to plug in the encoder wire into the spark max. With two motors, the positions will always end up differing, even if they start the same, because no two motors are exactly the same, and so the controller won’t be able to power the correct phases for each of the motors at the same time (thinking about it, it might cause some movement, but it would definitely be suboptimal and might cause damage).

Here are some videos I just found about how brushless motors work:

With older brushed motors, this works, because the output wires for care just simple DC electricity, and don’t depend. The motor uses physical brushes to turn on and off the right electromagnet in the motors.

One problem you can run into with connecting two brushed motors to the same controller is that controller may be rated to only handle a certain amount of current, so if you have two large motors connected you might have issues up to an including damage. But the rules do allow you to run two small motors off the same controller.
